content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one, very interesting and a little bit hard to find the order of the counts. Could be interesting in reverse mode too.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It could be quite tricky, but the hint really helps balancing the difficulty.
Good one.
Since you have changed it from reverse to fastest, you need to include a statement that explains what you need to do.

It's a good idea. I would advise you to change the first test case however, as it seems that it does matter in which order the numbers are returned, i.e. lower -> upper -> numbers -> special. Using 1111 as the first test doesn't convey this order, because there's an equal number of each. Validator 3 would be a good first example as you can clearly see in which order it needs to be returned, without it being too obvious.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The idea is fun, not too easy and not too difficult
It's going to be tricky to make this possible for reverse mode. You might consider explaining how to solve it in the statement and changing the game modes to fastest and shortest.

This is a fun idea, but it's close to impossible in its current form.

You need at least 2 more easy test cases for this to be feasible (i.e. max of 4 characters each), though because of the complexity of the problem, I would actually go for 4 extra cases.

To solve this puzzle, you have to figure out:
(1) the sequence of characters does not matter (a critical clue),
(2) there are four types of characters
(3) when a character type is missing from the input, the output is treated differently,
(4) the order of the output
(5) how to treat spaces

Some of these are not properly addressed in the current test case suite (especially #1). Besides, 5 test cases to figure out 5 things at once (maybe even more) is unreasonable for the time limit of a CoC.

(1) the sequence of characters does not matter (a critical clue) -> Agree to this, I can put this as hint.
2) I have planned to add it as 'Reverse mode' but as this is my first contribution I am not sure if I have created it correctly where the solver can see all inputs and outputs and get a good hint.
3) yes, this is critical but might be looking at all cases one can figure it out.
4) Let's ignore spaces.
I will add more test cases.
uhh your hint in output will not be seen in reverse, and I think this is a bit too unintuitive for reverse
